ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about important circuitry in the brain and how complex responses can be. It was so interesting to learn about how interconnected brain regions are.
I developed skills on reading and synthesizing complex research papers as well as being exposed to a variety of topics that I haven't really read about before.

I gained invaluable insight in the field of psychiatry through this course. I also found it very helpful practice for reading long and dense scientific articles and taking away the most important findings.

I was able to work on critically thinking and analyzing literature in the neuroscience field. The readings allowed me to understand what researchers have concluded in several topics regarding neuroscience and psychopathology.

I learned about how little we actually know in the field of psychiatry, and how to debate different points of ethics within neuroscience and psychology. I also learned a lot about different genetics and human connectome research.

After taking this class, I feel significantly more confident in my ability to read and critically think about academic papers. I also felt like I have been exposed to a lot of the "politics" or history of the psychiatric field which I had never been exposed to before and found it really interesting.
Learned how to critically read research papers and the ethical implications of current discoveries in clinical neuroscience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the structure. I found the weekly reading response to be very manageable and the jumpstarts were so interesting every time. Professor Holmes is so experienced and provided great insights during our discussions.
I really liked the course. It was rather intimidating to be in a room with others who have more knowledge on the topics than I do, but I still found the discussions interesting and engaging.

I really enjoyed the course; I thought that it was formatted well to ensure that students were doing the readings (via the weekly reading responses) and engaging with the content via our weekly, insightful class discussions. I thought it was an excellent environment to facilitate learning.

I enjoyed getting the opportunity to discuss the readings with other students and practicing giving presentations in scientific literature. Overall, the structure of reading the papers and then discussing in class is something I really enjoyed.

The strengths are the papers are really interesting and the jump starts are a good way of having students themselves lead the conversation! Professor Holmes also does a good job of stepping in to help us especially understand certain things we might not know or talk about his past research experience. Some weaknesses might be that we didn't really have a brain systems primer or it wasn't as particularly neuroscience-focused in driving home that we understood the brain in its entirety like what specific systems are responsible for or focused on.
This was a really interesting, yet low stress course that I still gained a lot from.
Having to summarise readings helped to keep me accountable to my readings. It might have been improved if there was a bit more lecturing from prof Avram.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, 100%. The content is so interesting.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested and has either a large or small knowledge of neuroscience topics. I learned a lot from this course and it directed me to specific fields that I might be interested in pursuing myself.
Yes! Professor Holmes is wonderful and I found our weekly discussions to be very interesting.
Yes!

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in learning about clinical neuroscience. Professor Holmes does a great job of facilitating discussions about complex and fascinating topics, and it's a great learning experience.
If one was interested in pursuing a career in neuroscience, this course is super helpful in understanding what the field is about and the current efforts in discovering more about the human brain.
Yes!

I would! We discussed really pertinent and interesting topics related to neuroscience and the field of psychiatry, and I really was able to understand how conflicting the research within the field is it's crazy how we really don't know anything about depression and schizophrenia, and that there is conflicting research for current and potential treatments. I really would recommend because it opened my eyes and was a relatively chill/easy senior neuroscience seminar.
Absolutely! The class is way more chill than the syllabus makes it seem, and the subject matter is super interesting. Professor Holmes is also very knowledgeable and a great discussion leader.
Yes absolutely! The content of this course can be applied to students of wide array of backgrounds.
Yes, it is a good chance for students to explore their interests in clinical neuroscience and be guided through that exploration through class discussions.
